zone.line: moment of our meeting. On the eve
of the third day I retired early to my
room; I could not sleep but paced
all night about my chamber and,
as you may in Scotland at midsummer,
watched the track crimson track
of the sun as it almost skirted the
northern horizon. At day break I
hastened to the woods; the hours past
on while I indulged in wild dreams
that cheated gave wings to the sloth-
ful steps of time, and beguiled my
eager impatience. My father was
expected at noon but when I wished
to return to met him I fou I found
that I had lost my way: It seemed
that in every attempt to find it
I only became more involved in the
intricacies of the woods, and the trees
hid all trace by which I might be guided.
I grew impatient, I wept; I and wrung
my hands but still I could not discover
my path.
